name: Nancy Pelosi
content:
Today, I signed H.R. 49, which will create the National Pulse Memorial at the site of the Pulse Nightclub in Orlando, Florida. Five years ago, a gunman killed 49 people and wounded 53 others there. It's really important for survivors to know we are not going away until the job is done.

Pulse was a peaceful haven, where mostly young, mostly LGBTQ Americans could enjoy music, dancing and celebration – a sense of community. Our hearts break again thinking of how this sanctuary of safety and solidarity was violated by this horrific act of hatred, leaving behind unimaginable pain in the Orlando community. Shortly after the shooting, I had the privilege – the solemn privilege – of traveling to Pulse to meet with the brave survivors and the families who lost ones and those who have established Pulse.

Their message was a clear and simple one: “Stop the violence. Don't let this happen to other people.”

name: Rand Paul
content:
Did 2020 just drive you up a wall? Do you ever just want to check out for a few hours, sit in a hot tub, and let the world melt away? Well, if you’re one of the 50 lucky participants in a study housed at the University of Oregon, you have that opportunity.

Not kidding! The National Institutes of Health is spending $2,004,704 to see if spending time in a hot tub three times a week for ten weeks relieves stress!

No… really. That’s actually what they’re doing. Researchers are testing the hypothesis that “30 sessions of passive heat therapy using hot water immersion over 8-10 weeks will improve blood pressure in HTN [hypertension] individuals to a greater extent than exercise.”

So, they’re going to put some people in hot tubs, and others on exercise bikes, and see which group has lower stress at the end. Why are they testing this? According to the researchers, “the vast majority of people are reticent to initiate exercise training and compliance in exercise regimens that meet minimum standards are extremely low.”

In other words? These researchers think Americans are lazy, very lazy. So, researchers argue, if heat therapy works, we can send lazy Americans who don’t feel like exercising to sit in hot tubs to solve their hypertension problem. What a wonderful use of Americans’ tax dollars, right?

However, if sitting in a hot tub for hours on end was not enough incentive to make people participate in the study, researchers are paying – that’s right – paying participants $600 to sit in a hot tub.

Oh, to be a participant in this study… I just have one question — is it too late for me to sign up, too?

name: Rand Paul
content:
#wastereportwednesday

Researchers at Dartmouth College in New Hampshire, as a part of the Auracle Project, made a prototype of a wearable earpiece designed to capture the “sound of a person chewing as it passes through the bone and tissue of the wearer’s head.” The idea was to create “a wearable earpiece that can automatically recognize eating behavior.”

That’s it, that’s how they spent your money – on a glorified microphone. They wanted to develop something comfortable that could detect eating sessions, as a first step in a long-term goal of having people wear earpieces that could track calorie intake, in an effort to “support the validation and deployment of effective behavioral-health interventions that promote healthy diet and behavior.”

Sounds like a novel idea, right? Well, as it turns out, there’s already a privately-funded company attempting to do effectively the same thing as this NSF-funded endeavor. Attempting to help assuage chronic diseases such as diabetes or eating disorders by improving “food journaling,” which they argue “is subject to self-bias and recall errors,” the team proposed a new item: “EarBit, a wearable system that detects eating moments.”

To make matters worse, the NSF awarded funds to the Dartmouth research team AFTER the private team published their work. It remains to be seen how either the EarBit or Auracle work out in practice. But it is already clear that the government shouldn’t be propping up a retread of a privately funded research team. If this system works, let the team that thought of it and raised the money on their own prosper off their ingenuity. And if it should fail, it is irresponsible to socialize the risk among the American taxpaying public by subsidizing the taxpayer-funded competitor’s effort.

name: Nancy Pelosi
content:
Economic inequality has been a growing concern for years – one that has intensified during the pandemic. The widening chasm between CEO compensation and worker pay has gone from unfair to immoral. There is recognition that our economy, which is based on free-market capitalism, has not served many Americans well. And it has become clear that the stagnation of workers’ pay is an historic picture of injustice.

The priority of addressing wealth and financial disparity is a broad one, encompassing many concerns and constituencies. That is why I am proud to name the following Members to the Select Committee on Economic Disparity and Fairness in Growth, who reflect the array of these challenges:

Congressman Jim Himes of Connecticut: bringing extensive professional experience from the private sector and in affordable housing, will be Chair.
Congresswoman Marcy Kaptur of Ohio: focusing on regional economic revitalization.
Congresswoman Gwen Moore of Wisconsin: leading action to close the racial wealth gap.
Congressman Vicente Gonzalez of Texas: recognizing the connection between economic growth and infrastructure connectivity.
Congresswoman Pramila Jayapal of Washington: delivering workers better wages and a brighter future.
Congresswoman Angie Craig of Minnesota: representing the concerns of family farmers and rural communities.
Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York: addressing generational disparities and increasing worker power in the economy.
Congresswoman Sara Jacobs of California: focusing on the future of work with both a family and a global perspective.

The Select Committee will study and recommend proposals to make our economy work for everyone, powering American economic growth while ensuring that no one is left out or left behind in the 21st Century Economy.

That is our mission: with this Committee, we can Build Back Better in a way that ensures liberty, prosperity and opportunity for all.

name: Thomas Massie
content:
I voted "NO" on S.475. Here's why:

"I fully support creating a day to celebrate the abolition of slavery, a dark portion of our nation’s history. However, naming this day “National Independence Day” will create confusion and push Americans to pick one of those two days as their Independence Day based on their racial identity. Why can’t we name this “Emancipation Day” and come together as Americans and celebrate that day together as Americans, black and white, all colors, all races, all ethnicities?

And then come together on “Independence Day,” which celebrates the creation of our country, throwing off an oppressive government. Come together as black and white and all races and celebrate that day, too. Why ask Americans to pick one of the two independence days to celebrate? I think it is wrong to do that. I think this day is misnamed.

I do support creating a holiday and recognizing that wonderful day, that wonderful time when we got rid of slavery in this country. But let’s celebrate both of those dates, “Independence Day” and the day that we celebrate emancipation and ridding our country of slavery. Let’s celebrate those two days, together, as one nation under God, indivisible."

name: Thomas Massie
content:
It's time to end the Iraq War, sell our $750 million embassy, and bring our troops home. This morning, I spoke on the House floor to urge my colleagues to repeal the 2002 Authorization for the Use of Military Force (AUMF) in Iraq.

The original text of the 2002 AUMF is disturbingly broad and authorizes the United States military to enforce United Nations Security Council resolutions. In 2003, we defeated Saddam Hussein. In 2011, President Obama declared the Iraq war over. However, the 2002 AUMF has never been repealed, and it gives a blank check to any current or future administration to keep American soldiers in Iraq indefinitely.

During our presence in Iraq, we've wasted $750 million on the world's largest embassy. When we get out of Iraq, it's time to put a "For Sale" sign on that embassy. We may only get pennies on the dollars, but that's better than sacrificing additional lives.

Our soldiers signed up to protect our country. They didn't sign up to be the world's policemen. It's time to repeal the 2002 AUMF for Iraq and bring our troops home.

name: Nancy Pelosi
content:
Juneteenth is one of the most momentous events in our history and has been celebrated by millions for 156 years

Juneteenth is a beautiful and proud celebration of freedom for Black Americans. It marks the day, two years after President Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation, when Major General Gordon Granger and Union soldiers delivered the news of liberation in Galveston, Texas. That day, General Granger declared that all are free with the absolute equality of rights and rights of property.

Thanks to tonight's bipartisan vote, it will soon be officially recognized as a federal holiday and take its place of honor in our nation.

The Joe Biden-Nancy Pelosi-Chuck Schumer “Green” crusade against American energy independence and jobs hit a snag yesterday: a federal judge stepped in to block the Biden administration’s ban on new oil and gas leasing on federal lands. This is welcome news.

While Vladimir Putin is building a massive natural gas pipeline (Nord Stream 2) to Germany – the revenue from which he’ll continue to fuel his military and maintain his nukes aimed at us -\-\ the Biden administration is doing everything it can to stop traditional, proven domestic energy development here in America. The Biden-Pelosi-Schumer plan is simple: provide massive taxpayer subsidies to blanket America’s landscape in solar panels and windmills (except where the wealthy live…because they don’t like the view) and hope for the best.

The judge’s order is good news for hard-working Americans – the millions of men and women working energy jobs, and every consumer who depends on affordable, reliable energy to cook their meals and cool their homes when they want, rather than having to wait for the sun to shine or for the wind to blow.

name: Ralph Norman
content:
Obviously Juneteenth is an incredibly significant commemoration for our country. Nobody disputes that, and nobody disputes the *overwhelming* importance of emancipation. I certainly understand that.

But earlier this evening, the House held a vote to make Juneteenth yet ANOTHER national holiday called… get this… “Juneteenth Independence Day.” I have a few problems with this and voted against the bill, so let’s get the air cleared before you start reading lies claiming that I somehow oppose emancipation, or other ridiculous remarks.

First of all, our Independence Day is July 4th. Period. Independence Day celebrates the anniversary of our declared independence from Great Britain, and it’s been that way for 245 years. If you want to call Juneteenth, for example, Freedom Day or Emancipation Day then fine – that’s certainly worth considering. But calling it Independence Day is WHOLLY INAPPROPIATE.

Second, we can’t just add new federal holidays without considering the ramifications! When Obama issued an executive order in 2014 giving federal employees an extra day off, that cost the government roughly $660 MILLION dollars, according to the Congressional Budget Office. So given inflation and the obnoxious growth of the federal government, this means a Juneteenth holiday should easily cost the federal government over a billion dollars Every. Single. Year. in federal payroll & holiday premiums with no offsets!

We have no idea what the impact of ANY of this will be on the government or private sector. Why? Well that’s my third point. It’s because Nancy Pelosi decided to ram this through without what’s known as “regular order.” By that I mean, there were no hearings, no cost analysis by the CBO, nothing! As reverential as Juneteenth is, this is NO WAY to run the legislative branch of government.

And fourth, since Biden was elected, we now have an inflation crisis, an immigration crisis, a floundering foreign policy, and a host of other problems. There are significant issues facing this nation. It’s time we start actually facing them.
text: obviously juneteenth incredibly significant commemoration country nobody disputes nobody disputes overwhelming importance emancipation certainly understand thatbut earlier evening house held vote make juneteenth yet another national holiday called get juneteenth independence day problems voted bill lets get air cleared start reading lies claiming somehow oppose emancipation ridiculous remarksfirst independence day july 4th period independence day celebrates anniversary declared independence great britain way years want call juneteenth example freedom day emancipation day fine thats certainly worth considering calling independence day wholly inappropiatesecond cant add new federal holidays without considering ramifications obama issued executive order giving federal employees extra day cost government roughly million dollars according congressional budget office given inflation obnoxious growth federal government means juneteenth holiday easily cost federal government billion dollars every single year federal payroll holiday premiums offsetswe idea impact government private sector well thats third point nancy pelosi decided ram without whats known regular order mean hearings cost analysis cbo nothing reverential juneteenth way run legislative branch governmentand fourth since biden elected inflation crisis immigration crisis floundering foreign policy host problems significant issues facing nation time start actually facing

content:
When Oregon went up in flames last September, I drove over 600 miles across the state to meet affected families and inspect the widespread damage. It is difficult to put into words the heartbreak you feel when you see streets leveled and empty lots of rubble where homes stood just days before. It’s impossible to thrive without a safe roof over your head, making it absolutely crucial that families whose homes went up in flames receive the resources they need to rebuild.

I’m going to keep pushing for housing resources—both emergency and long-term—and other assistance to ensure that all Oregonians impacted by this year’s wildfire season receive the support they need to get back on their feet as quickly as possible.

MERKLEY.SENATE.GOV
Following Extremely Destructive 2020 Wildfire Season: Merkley, Wyden Push Biden Administration for Disaster Supplemental Funding to Help Communities Rebuild | U.S. Senator Jeff Merkley of Oregon

name: Mark Takano
content: We’ve all been there – we sign up for a free trial and start getting charged monthly without a warning that the free trial has expired. And when we try to cancel the subscription, companies make the cancelation process a nightmare. This deceptive practice should be prohibited. Today I reintroduced the Unsubscribe Act to fix this by forcing companies to get consumers' explicit permission before charging them, allowing consumers to cancel a service through a straightforward process, and ensuring companies are transparent about cost and cancellation policies.

name: Chris Van Hollen
content: Good news! The Senate just confirmed Judge Lydia Griggsby to serve on Maryland’s U.S. District Court with bipartisan support. Judge Griggsby—a lifelong Maryland resident— is the first Black woman and first woman of color to serve as a district court judge in our state. She has spent over twenty years in public service, fighting for Americans’ rights in a wide range of roles including on the bench, in Congress, and at the Department of Justice. Her commitment to justice for all is exactly what we need in our courts.

name: James M. Inhofe
content:
Our world is more dangerous than it’s been in my lifetime – President Biden has acknowledged that on his trip to Europe this week. Yet his budget inexplicably cuts money for defense. How does that make sense? How can we address threats from near peers like China and Russia without adequate investment?

This Wall Street Journal editorial has it right: “China, Iran and Vladimir Putin would be more impressed if Mr. Biden wasn’t cutting America’s defense even as he rightly stresses the challenge from the world’s authoritarians.”

This isn’t about more ships or tanks or guns. It’s about giving ourselves a chance in this competition against China and Russia.

https://www.wsj.com/articles/threats-rise-u-s-defense-falls-11623798082?mod=opinion_lead_pos1

name: Bill Johnson
content:
President Biden is meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin today in Geneva. This important meeting will be set against the backdrop of the Russian military conducting what it describes as its largest military exercise in the Pacific since the Cold War, 300 miles off of Hawaii. Long range Russian bombers flew close enough to American soil yesterday that several of our F-22s were scrambled. The meeting also occurs shortly after Joe Biden caved and dropped sanctions against the Russians building a natural gas pipeline to Germany to meet Europe’s energy needs. Putin will receive billions in the deal and Europe will increase its dependence on Putin and Russian energy.

The last time the Democrats were in the White House, Putin invaded Ukraine despite President Obama’s pleas not to. And now, after four years of containment, Russia seems to be on the march again.

name: Jeff Duncan
content:
I am happy to announce that I am an original cosponsor of the PRIME Act, which will help local farmers sell meat directly to local consumers using local meat processors.

Did you know only four multinational corporations control over 70% of US beef processing? And in many instances, these processors that employ a USDA inspector can be located hours away from our local farmers. The practice of vertical consolidation in the meat industry has left both farmers and consumers with limited options for processing their meat locally.

But the PRIME Act would give states the option of setting their own rules for processing meat that's sold inside state borders.

Senator Angus King (yes, that's really his name) is an Independent Senator from Maine, and he just introduced the bill in the Senate. So this bill is also both tripartisan and bicameral.

CONGRESS.GOV
H.R.3835 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): To amend the Federal Meat Inspection Act to exempt from inspection the slaughter of animals and the preparation of carcasses conducted at a custom slaughter facility, and for other purposes.
text: happy announce original cosponsor prime act help local farmers sell meat directly local consumers using local meat processorsdid know four multinational corporations control us beef processing many instances processors employ usda inspector located hours away local farmers practice vertical consolidation meat industry left farmers consumers limited options processing meat locallybut prime act would give states option setting rules processing meat thats sold inside state borderssenator angus king yes thats really name independent senator maine introduced bill senate bill also tripartisan bicameralcongressgovhr3835 117th congress amend federal meat inspection act exempt inspection slaughter animals preparation carcasses conducted custom slaughter facility purposes

name: Jeff Duncan
content:
President Biden's unwise and misguided economic policies have resulted in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) for May to accelerate at the fastest pace in nearly 13 years. Inflation pressure is building, and Americans can't afford for him to continue to get this so wrong.

- Gasoline is 56.2% MORE expensive today than 12 months ago

- CPI in May 2021 increased 0.6% that is a 5% INCREASE from May 2020

- Transportation services are up 11.2% since May 2020

- Food and energy prices have increased 3.8%, which is the fastest rate since 1992

- Fastest rate of inflation since right before the economic crisis in 2008

CNBC.COM
Consumer prices jump 5% in May, fastest pace since the summer of 2008

name: Jim Banks
content:
Yesterday at an Armed Services Committee I questioned Admiral Gilday about his decision to include Ibram X. Kendi’s “How to Be an Antiracist” on the Navy’s official reading list. Kendi’s book argues that America is fundamentally racist and must be fixed through racial discrimination.

The Navy just completed a standdown to remove extremism from the ranks, because extremism detracts from the Navy’s readiness. But the Navy also officially endorsed Kendi, who holds extremist views.

Not only does Kendi think America and the Navy are racist, he’s criticized interracial adoption and argued that American Capitalism is racist and must be destroyed. Kendi’s beliefs clearly violate the oath to defend the Constitution that all Sailors take when they join the Navy.

Kendi’s extremist belief that America and the Navy are racist and evil will reduce the Navy’s cohesion, morale, retention rates and recruitment.

The Pentagon is right: extremism does detract from our military’s readiness. That’s one reason they should immediately stop promoting Kendi’s poisonous extremism.

I asked Admiral Gilday to explain why he would promote a crank like Kendi. His answers weren’t very satisfying. Watch, below:

name: Chris Van Hollen
content: Americans have a right to know how our broken tax system is rewarding corporations that ship jobs overseas. That’s why U.S. Representative Cindy Axne and I introduced the Disclosure of Tax Havens and Offshoring Act — to shine a light on these tax loopholes and expose why we must close them. When companies do this, it only hurts public investments here at home. As we work to remedy the damage done by the GOP Tax Scam of 2017 and create jobs here, I’m glad to see the House pass our bill today as part of a larger package aimed at increasing corporate transparency. I’ll keep working in the Senate to pass this legislation so that all Americans reap the benefits of a tax system that puts their needs first.

name: Doug LaMalfa
content:
Here we go again, another legislative week and another large part of the week was spent debating a pointless virtue signaling bill. This time it’s the “wokeness report card” for businesses. This bill would impose burdensome, complicated, and useless private sector mandates on public companies to report unnecessary information to investors about environmental, social, and governance (ESG) impacts. Subjects found in these reports include: carbon emissions, biodiversity, inclusivity, and the racial, ethnic, and gender composition of company board seats.

Investors don’t need a ‘wokeness’ report card on a company’s long-term business strategy. Through this bill, Democrats will use bureaucrats to forcibly collect information that progressive interest groups will use to publicly harass American companies. Reports through the Securities and Exchange Commission should be designed to better inform investors about a company’s financial health and relative risk, not to promote cancel culture.
text: go another legislative week another large part week spent debating pointless virtue signaling bill time wokeness report card businesses bill would impose burdensome complicated useless private sector mandates public companies report unnecessary information investors environmental social governance esg impacts subjects found reports include carbon emissions biodiversity inclusivity racial ethnic gender composition company board seatsinvestors dont need wokeness report card companys longterm business strategy bill democrats use bureaucrats forcibly collect information progressive interest groups use publicly harass american companies reports securities exchange commission designed better inform investors companys financial health relative risk promote cancel culture

name: Robert P. Casey, Jr.
content:
This past weekend, we remembered the 49 people murdered at Pulse – the deadliest attack on the LGBTQ community in US history. Tomorrow, we will mark the 6th anniversary of the Charleston massacre and remember the 9 African Americans murdered by a white extremist at Mother Emanuel.

In 2018, congregants at the Tree of Life in Pittsburgh were attacked by an anti-Semitic shooter and 11 people lost their lives. In honor of the victims & amidst a wave of anti-Asian hate, we must fight for legislation that protects all Americans from acts of hateful violence.

I encourage my colleagues to support the Disarm Hate Act, which would prohibit individuals convicted of violent or threatening hate crimes from obtaining a gun and prevent further tragedies.

CASEY.SENATE.GOV
Casey, Cicilline Introduce Disarm Hate Act to Keep Guns Away from Hate Crime Offenders | U.S. Senator for Pennsylvania

name: Angus S. King, Jr.
content:
The pandemic has made it clear that broadband is essential infrastructure – but for too many Americans, a high-speed connection remains out of reach. That's why Senator Michael Bennet, Senator Rob Portman, and I introduced the BRIDGE Act to invest in broadband.

Every American, in every community across our nation, should be able to access the internet’s economic, educational, and social possibilities. The BRIDGE Act will build upon the historic broadband funding included in the American Rescue Plan to make that vision a reality by investing $40 billion in resilient, future-proof broadband infrastructure. Our bipartisan legislation would be a monumental step in confronting the digital divide plaguing rural and low-income communities, and help ensure that Americans of all backgrounds can access an affordable, high-speed broadband connection.

WASHINGTONPOST.COM
Bipartisan group of senators introduces $40 billion bill to close the digital divide

name: Mitch McConnell
content:
In my state of Kentucky, the consequences of Democrats’ misguided spending are growing more serious. Small business owners, in particular, are nearing a breaking point.

One restaurant owner in Clark County wrote to me to say that, quote, ‘each week it gets harder to create a full schedule. Restaurants are already reducing hours of operation. Next will come closing.’

I’ve heard the same story from constituents all over the Commonwealth.

A sign manufacturer in Woodford County has had to ask his staff to work as many as ten hours of overtime each week just to keep up with demand.

An outdoor supplies maker in McCracken County saw shipping costs increase quadruple in the past year. He can’t find a prospective employee who will even show up for an interview. After twenty-five years of production, he’s facing the prospect that his company may not be able to stay afloat.

The Commonwealth still has 90,000 fewer workers than we did before the pandemic. In the past year, the consumer price index in Kentucky and surrounding states has increased by a whopping 7%.

The recovery teed up by smart, targeted, bipartisan policies last year has been buried under an ill-advised, self-inflicted avalanche of spending.

Folks in #Kentucky know all too well what happens when Democrats get carried away in Washington. They know who ends up footing the bill back home.

Higher prices at the gas pump and the grocery store, just as families were hoping to put a year of sacrifices in the rearview mirror.

These are the real-world effects of the Biden Administration’s multi-trillion-dollar economic debacle. These are the effects that Republicans and nonpartisan experts have warned about for months.

The American people are resilient. Job creators, innovators, and skilled workers are ready. But as our economy slowly gets back up to speed, it won’t be because Democrats stroked an outsized check. It’ll be in spite of it: https://sen.gov/48OO
text: state kentucky consequences democrats misguided spending growing serious small business owners particular nearing breaking pointone restaurant owner clark county wrote say quote week gets harder create full schedule restaurants already reducing hours operation next come closingive heard story constituents commonwealtha sign manufacturer woodford county ask staff work many ten hours overtime week keep demandan outdoor supplies maker mccracken county saw shipping costs increase quadruple past year cant find prospective employee even show interview twentyfive years production hes facing prospect company may able stay afloatthe commonwealth still fewer workers pandemic past year consumer price index kentucky surrounding states increased whopping 7the recovery teed smart targeted bipartisan policies last year buried illadvised selfinflicted avalanche spendingfolks kentucky know well happens democrats get carried away washington know ends footing bill back homehigher prices gas pump grocery store families hoping put year sacrifices rearview mirrorthese realworld effects biden administrations multitrilliondollar economic debacle effects republicans nonpartisan experts warned monthsthe american people resilient job creators innovators skilled workers ready economy slowly gets back speed wont democrats stroked outsized check itll spite

name: Brian Schatz
content:
From news to fashion, music to food, subscriptions are everywhere in today’s economy. But when you sign up for a free trial, you shouldn’t have to jump through hoops just to cancel your subscription before being charged. Too many companies use deceptive practices to lure and trap in customers. That needs to change.

Today, I introduced the bipartisan Unsubscribe Act – which will require companies to be more transparent about their subscriptions and to make it easier for customers to avoid costly, automatic monthly charges they never intended to make.

ENGADGET.COM
US lawmakers want to make it easier for people to cancel their subscriptions | Engadget

name: Jaime Herrera Beutler
content:
The Constitution’s 4th Amendment enshrines Americans' right to privacy, and with rapid advances in our technology, we should update our laws to protect those rights.

Recent reports have revealed federal agencies have been purchasing Americans' geolocation data to pinpoint their mobile device locations, and doing so without first obtaining a warrant. This type of overreach violates 4th amendment protections and it’s why Congress should take action.

I’m introducing legislation to force the government to follow due process and stop federal agencies from accessing law-abiding citizens' sensitive information, like geolocation data from a phone or an app, without first obtaining a warrant.

CHRONLINE.COM
Herrera Beutler Introduces Bill Requiring Search Warrant for Geolocation Data
text: constitutions 4th amendment enshrines americans right privacy rapid advances technology update laws protect rightsrecent reports revealed federal agencies purchasing americans geolocation data pinpoint mobile device locations without first obtaining warrant type overreach violates 4th amendment protections congress take actionim introducing legislation force government follow due process stop federal agencies accessing lawabiding citizens sensitive information like geolocation data phone app without first obtaining warrantchronlinecomherrera beutler introduces bill requiring search warrant geolocation data

name: Doug LaMalfa
content:
Congressman McClintock and I recently submitted comments to the State Board of Forestry about their proposed regulatory changes for development in Very High Fire Hazard Severity Zones. We highlighted concerns we have heard from constituents and local governments about how these regulations could prevent post fire rebuilding or make it cost prohibitive to do so.

The State of California already has very strict building codes that have both driven up the cost to rebuild and disincentivized development and new home construction, driving the costs of all housing to record levels. These regulations would add another layer to the already burdensome requirements that would make this situation much worse. The local communities that are prone to wildfire and the residents who reside and rebuild there are the first line of defense in taking steps necessary to prevent wildfire. Passing the responsibility of the state and federal government to better manage it’s land onto those trying to rebuild their homes is a feckless attempt to drive residents from rural areas and the freedom to live where they choose.

I urge the State Board of Forestry to take more time speaking directly with the people that would be harmed by these policies and to make changes to the proposed regulations that incorporates the feedback from people in the areas impacted.
text: congressman mcclintock recently submitted comments state board forestry proposed regulatory changes development high fire hazard severity zones highlighted concerns heard constituents local governments regulations could prevent post fire rebuilding make cost prohibitive sothe state california already strict building codes driven cost rebuild disincentivized development new home construction driving costs housing record levels regulations would add another layer already burdensome requirements would make situation much worse local communities prone wildfire residents reside rebuild first line defense taking steps necessary prevent wildfire passing responsibility state federal government better manage land onto trying rebuild homes feckless attempt drive residents rural areas freedom live choosei urge state board forestry take time speaking directly people would harmed policies make changes proposed regulations incorporates feedback people areas impacted

name: Neal P. Dunn
content:
Last week, a sperm whale was found beached on Shell Island. While this is a very rare occurrence and one that I hope we'll never experience again, I want to give you some important information should you find a stranded marine mammal --

If you encounter a stranded marine mammal, please do not approach it or push it back into the water. The mammal is probably sick or injured.

Please report the encounter to MyFWC Florida Fish and Wildlife at (888) 404-3922 or use a cell phone to dial #FWC. You can also contact the NOAA Fisheries Southeast Marine Mammal Stranding Hotline at (877) WHALE-HELP (877-942-5343). These are trained experts who can get the animal the care it needs.

I would like to say a special thank you to Lauren Albritton, Stranding Coordinator at the Gulf World Marine Institute, and to the other responders for taking the time to speak with me and for all of the important work they do to care for our marine life and beaches.

name: Bob Gibbs
content:
This survey on Americans’ inflation worries is jarring. It reported that 70% of participants – Republican, Democrat, and Independent – are concerned that President Biden’s spending plans could lead to inflation. Even Larry Summers, a top economic adviser under President Obama, has called it the “least responsible” economic policy seen in 40 years.

The Biden administration is pushing the country towards the highest inflation rates since 1979, while his big-spending budget proposals pretend inflation doesn’t even exist. 𝘽𝙪𝙩 𝙬𝙚 𝙖𝙧𝙚 𝙖𝙡𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙𝙮 𝙨𝙚𝙚𝙞𝙣𝙜 𝙞𝙩. The CPI increased 4.2% from April 2020 to April 2021 and 5% from May 2020 to May 2021, part of the highest 12-month increase we’ve had since the 2008 recession. President Biden’s economically illiterate policies are hurting the very Americans he claims to be helping.

name: Jack Bergman
content:
Currently, the Social Security Administration (SSA) pays most beneficiaries on the second, third, or fourth Wednesday of every month - forcing recipients to wait 35 days between payments four times each year. This has led to increased financial instability among beneficiaries. The Social Security Benefit Payments Choice Act will allow Social Security retirement and disability beneficiaries to choose the day they would like to receive payments. According to the SSA, the change in this bill is expected to benefit 28 million Americans.

The current schedule of Social Security payments creates uncertainty and hardship for thousands of seniors every year. Allowing recipients to choose the date they receive their benefits is a simple way we can create financial stability without increasing costs for taxpayers or the Social Security Administration. I’m proud to join Rep Carol Miller in introducing this commonsense legislation to improve the lives of seniors nationwide.

BERGMAN.HOUSE.GOV
Bergman, Miller Introduce Legislation to Provide Social Security Beneficiaries More Stability
text: currently social security administration ssa pays beneficiaries second third fourth wednesday every month forcing recipients wait days payments four times year led increased financial instability among beneficiaries social security benefit payments choice act allow social security retirement disability beneficiaries choose day would like receive payments according ssa change bill expected benefit million americansthe current schedule social security payments creates uncertainty hardship thousands seniors every year allowing recipients choose date receive benefits simple way create financial stability without increasing costs taxpayers social security administration im proud join rep carol miller introducing commonsense legislation improve lives seniors nationwidebergmanhousegovbergman miller introduce legislation provide social security beneficiaries stability

name: Tom Emmer
content: A federal government land grab—or by another name, the Biden Administration’s 30 x 30 initiative is an effort to reclaim 30% of all lands and water (including those privately owned!) by 2030. This will threaten Minnesota farmers, ranchers, miners, and more who depend on the land for their livelihoods. My Minnesota Republican colleagues and I sent a letter to President Biden asking his administration to clarify how this effort will hurt Minnesotans. Read more on my website here: https://emmer.house.gov/_cache/files/9/0/90f41bd4-a216-4b8a-9c0c-ce4d3bc1f61a/8686E86007F233CB9D2C46ED49311CF5.30x30-signed-copy.pdf

name: Roger F. Wicker
content:
Our country is overdue for a large investment in local infrastructure, including roads, bridges, ports, and rail. In Memphis, for example, a structural crack has resulted in the closure of one interstate bridge across the Mississippi River, causing huge traffic pile-ups and forcing travelers to take detours through Lula, Mississippi, and Dyersburg, Tennessee. Communities across the nation are facing similar infrastructure challenges.

https://www.wicker.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2021/6/wicker-continues-push-for-infrastructure-deal

name: Jerrold Nadler
content:
Today's vote to make #Juneteenth a federal holiday is an important milestone in our nation's journey to reckon with the original sin at the heart of its history. But it can only be that: one milestone among more to come. Systemic racism is everywhere you look in America. It is in New York's parole system that disadvantages those with Black and Brown skin. It is in our brutal policing practices. It is in our education system, our polling places, and our public housing. It is not ancient history.

This vote represents progress—but the work must continue.
text: todays vote make juneteenth federal holiday important milestone nations journey reckon original sin heart history one milestone among come systemic racism everywhere look america new yorks parole system disadvantages black brown skin brutal policing practices education system polling places public housing ancient historythis vote represents progressbut work must continue

name: Debbie Stabenow
content:
For too long, we’ve funded health care above the neck differently than health care below the neck.

Why does that matter?

Because someone with a broken arm has a much easier time getting care than someone who is bipolar or struggling with a substance use disorder.

Here’s the good news - this is finally changing. Thanks to my partnership with Senator Roy Blunt, we are transforming how we deliver high quality behavioral health services in our communities.

name: Joe Wilson
content:
Once again, the President’s Budget has been delivered to Congress without payment in lieu of taxes (PiLT) for the Savannah River Site. Aiken, Barnwell, and Allendale counties rely on these funds to support the local school districts, emergency services, and county operations. In both Barnwell and Aiken counties, at least 50 percent of the PiLT money received goes to support the local school system.

With the Site continuing to grow with new missions, taking money out of local school districts will have a direct impact on the future workforce needs of the Site. I plan to work with Congressman Jim Clyburn and my Senate colleagues to reinstate these payments throughout the Congressional appropriations process.

POSTANDCOURIER.COM
Biden budget cuts millions of dollars for communities near Savannah River, Hanford

name: Jerry Moran
content:
Thank you to Fred Patton for his many years of serving USD 345, and his dedication to improving the lives of students and families throughout his role as the district’s Board President, as well as his position as President of the Kansas Association of School Boards. Educators work to better their communities one student at a time, and I thank Fred for his dedication to USD 345 and all those he had the opportunity to teach and mentor throughout his career.

Thank you to the teachers and Board of Education members across Kansas who work to better the lives of their students each day.

Fred Patton is at Seaman Schools.
June 15 at 4:14 PM ·

Board President James Adams recognized fellow Board Member Fred Patton for his 18 years on the USD 345 Board of Education. Representative Patton (also serving in the Kansas Legislature) recently announced his intent to retire from the USD 345 Board of Education, effective June 30, 2021, the end of the district’s fiscal year. "The time necessary to be an effective board member and an effective legislator have significantly increased over the past few years," stated Patton in his letter to Mr. Adams. "Doing both at the level I expect, and that the community deserves, is no longer feasible."

"Fred is our longest serving member of the board, serving since 2003, and has been involved with countless initiatives, committees, and leadership positions," said Mr. Adams. Representative Patton has served as USD 345 Board President a total of six times including President of the Kansas Association of School Boards from 2010 to 2012.

Mr. Adams acknowledged how Representative Patton's dedication, service and putting kids first has helped cement USD 345 as a premier destination for families to raise their children. "Fred has been a tremendous mentor, friend, model community advocate and leader," said Adams. "I wish him, his wife Kim, and their family well in their new found time together."

name: Robert C. "Bobby" Scott
content:
I was very proud to vote today to finally establish Juneteenth as a national holiday and I was pleased to see broad bipartisan support for the legislation. I look forward to President Joe Biden signing it in to law. This vote comes after the Commonwealth of Virginia formally recognized Juneteenth as a holiday last year and now a total of 49 states and Washington, D.C. now celebrate Juneteenth as a state or ceremonial holiday. The legacy of Juneteenth is a reminder of the way that justice and equality for Black people has too often been delayed in America. The past year has also been a stark reminder of all the work that is left to do to fulfill the founding promises of our nation.

I am committed to defending the gains we have made, stopping the back-sliding on civil rights and continuing the fight for equity in education, employment, health care, housing and the criminal justice system. Let us celebrate this action and all the progress we have made but may Juneteenth also be a reminder of the work that remains. And let us continue the work of fulfilling the promises of equality and justice for all people.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/juneteenth-federal-holiday/2021/06/16/7be284d8-ceba-11eb-a7f1-52b8870bef7c_story.html

WASHINGTONPOST.COM
Congress votes overwhelmingly to make Juneteenth a federal holiday. The day commemorates the end of slavery in Texas in 1865.

name: Richard Hudson
content:
This month, I led my colleagues in calling on President Biden to postpone today's summit with Vladimir Putin until he stops Russian cyberattacks on critical US infrastructure.

Since taking office, President Biden signed the New START Treaty without adding any US demands, allowed a cyberattack on our critical energy infrastructure and food supply, and ignored the will of Congress by granting a waiver for the Nord Stream II pipeline which gives Russia increased leverage over Europe.

I believe this summit rewards this bad behavior and sends the wrong message. However now, President Biden must do more to hold Russia accountable for its aggression in the US and around the globe. I am hopeful our countries could work together, but we must show resolve.

name: Don Young
content:
I proudly voted in support of making Juneteenth a federal holiday. This day is central to American history, the day when the last enslaved Black Americans learned they had been freed. Juneteenth is a celebration of human liberty, freedom, and resilience in the face of the terrible evil of slavery.

Juneteenth, recognized every year on June 19th, marks the day in 1865 when Union soldiers arrived in Galveston, Texas, to take control of the state and ensure that enslaved people would be free. The Emancipation Proclamation, issued two years earlier on January 1, 1863, established that all enslaved people "shall be then, thenceforward, and forever free." However, slavery remained relatively unhindered in Texas.

The Emancipation Proclamation didn't free all who were enslaved. It only applied to areas under Confederate control, not former Confederate territory that was taken by the Union or slave-holding border states. After Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered, Union General Gordon Granger's arrival in Galveston helped spread the message that the war was over and enslaved people were free. Celebrations broke out among newly freed Black Americans in the south, and the day known as Juneteenth was born.

I love this great country of ours, and we have always shown an incredible capacity to learn from our mistakes and do what is right. As President George W. Bush said, "the price of our Union was America's original sin," and the fact is that our country didn't afford liberty to everyone. Slavery was a colossal evil, and inflicted great pain on Black Americans.

Our Constitution has enshrined equal protection under the law; making Juneteenth a federal holiday will give us all the opportunity to reflect on what that means and how to protect this principle for generations to come.

name: Stacey E. Plaskett
content:
HR 3434 - The Territories Health Equity Act of 2021 which I introduced this Congress. HR 3434 would address existing inequalities the territories face under Medicaid, Medicare, and other federal health programs. Importantly, regarding Medicaid, it will provide them with their equitable share of federal funding for Medicaid beyond the upcoming “fiscal cliff” when much of the existing funding for the territories is scheduled to expire at the end of September 2021.

People in the territories should have just as much access to health care as anyone else. In the midst of global pandemic, with more federal attention on how health care funding disparities have had a deleterious impact on the finances of local governments and hospitals in the territories, we believe that this is an opportune time to press for equity in Medicaid and Medicare. The inequities in federal funding provided to the territories for Medicaid and Medicare has put access to affordable health care out of reach for too many Virgin Islanders, making our hospitals’ emergency rooms the primary health care provider for the one-third of our population without health insurance, which contributes to unmanageable costs in uncompensated care.

#VIStrong

America is in a debt crisis thanks to decades of wasteful Washington spending. As our national debt nears $30 trillion, we are seeing substantial increases in inflation, which means the prices of every day goods are going up for families in Florida and across the nation.

Government shouldn’t work this way. I’m proud to partner with The Heritage Foundation for a new series: Road Trip on a Budget, to highlight how we can work together to put America back on a fiscally responsible path forward. Tune in!

20 hrs ·

name: Chris Van Hollen
content:
When the pandemic hit, Maryland’s families and children were dealt extremely challenging circumstances. But during this time, Baltimore community schools stepped up to meet the urgency of this moment in so many ways —delivering food, providing mental health services, and even helping those facing eviction. These are just a few examples of the vital services our community schools can provide. This model not only provides our students with quality learning in the classroom, it also takes a broader approach at ensuring our local communities can succeed, through a variety of wraparound services. As we gain economic momentum in this post-pandemic recovery and beyond, families will continue to need resources that community schools provide. That’s why I’ve introduced the Full-Service Community School Expansion Act with U.S. Senator Sherrod Brown and U.S. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand to invest $3.65 billion over the next five years to plan, implement, expand, and support full-service community schools serving low-income students. When our communities thrive, our students succeed.

BALTIMOREBREW.COM
When Covid struck, Baltimore’s community schools became a lifeline | Baltimore Brew

name: Mike Thompson
content: Our district and our state knows firsthand that our nation’s electrical grid needs to be modernized to withstand extreme weather so we don’t continue to have Public Safety Power Shutoffs. These events hurt every day residents, threaten the lives of people who are medically vulnerable and impact our economy. Estimates show that the first shutoff in 2019 cost the California economy $2 billion. That’s why I support President Joe Biden's American Jobs Plan, a comprehensive infrastructure plan that includes plans to make our grid more resilient. That includes resources to modernize powerlines so they can get through extreme weather and people in our district don’t have to go days without power. I’ll continue working to pass this plan so we can make this important investments in our grid.

name: Joe Wilson
content:
Today I spoke on the House Floor on the border crisis. The southern border is in peril and this issue has been wholly created by the destructive new policies of President Biden. Immigrants flood the border while dangerous cartels take advantage of the Administration’s weak policies. There is truly a crisis and it’s time that President Biden and border “czar” Vice President Harris take action to prevent this crisis from getting worse.

The numbers speak for themselves. Encounters at the border reached a 21-year high last month, with 180,034 in total. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) announced they had seized 934 pounds of fentanyl at the border in May, which is a 300 percent increase from May 2020. Criminal crossings have almost tripled since the previous fiscal year to 6,918 individuals with criminal convictions.

Drug trafficking and human smuggling have also increased, continuing to put children’s lives in danger. Biden tasked his Vice President with overseeing this crisis, it has been 84 days and she has still not visited or scheduled a visit to the southern border.

name: Bill Foster
content:
I can’t think of a more important moment in American history to celebrate than the end of slavery. Illinois has led the way by making Juneteenth an official state holiday. Tonight, I was proud to vote to make Juneteenth a federal holiday as well.

Now more than ever, we can’t afford to forget slavery’s legacy on American history, and we should honor and celebrate the sacrifices made to end the horror of slavery in the United States. Juneteenth should serve as an opportunity for all of us to learn about our history, reflect on the progress we’ve made as a nation, and commit to the work we have yet to do to truly live up to our founding creed that all men and women are equal.

FOSTER.HOUSE.GOV
Foster Statement on Passage of Legislation Establishing Juneteenth as a Federal Holiday

name: John Garamendi
content:
I was honored to receive the 2021 Maritime Leadership Award tonight. Supporting the U.S. maritime industry is critically important for our economy and national security. That’s why I’ve spent my tenure in Congress fighting to end Congressional neglect of our maritime industry by introducing my ‘Energizing American Shipbuilding Act,’ which would recapitalize America’s domestic shipbuilding and maritime industries by requiring increasing percentages of liquified natural gas (LNG) and crude oil exports to be transported on U.S.-built ships.

As a senior member of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, I will always fight to support our vital maritime industry.

name: Trent Kelly
content: The House Armed Services Committee hosted a hearing to discuss President Biden's 2022 budget proposal for the Navy and Marine Corps. The $211 billion budget request is a 15% budget cut that will degrade our ability to protect the seas and jeopardize the lives of our men and women in uniform who are forced to fight a well-equipped enemy. There is a critical need to expand the number of ships at sea – a modern fleet of warfighters capable of defeating our enemies. Unfortunately, President Biden's proposed budget for the Department of Defense fails to prioritize our national defense requirements. Testimony was received from Acting Secretary of the Navy Thomas Harker, Chief of Naval Operations Admiral Michael Gilday, and Commandant of the Marine Corps General David Berger.

name: Jim Banks
content:
Yesterday my office participated in the launch of Neighborhood Health's new mobile services unit.

Because Fort Wayne is home to the largest Burmese community in America, all the resources in the mobile unit are in English, Spanish, and Burmese. The mobile unit includes an exam room, wifi access, and a generator for heating, cooling, and lighting.

I look forward to seeing how this new effort will continue to serve northeast Indiana.

name: Paul Tonko
content:
We know our water systems’ needs are immense.

The EPA’s 2018 Needs Survey estimated that over $472 billion is required to maintain our drinking water systems over the next 20 years.

And today, the federal share of water infrastructure spending pales in comparison to our contributions to roads and bridges spending.

We need to increase the federal commitment, which is what H.R. 3291 would do.

H.R. 3291, the AQUA Act, would reauthorize key drinking water programs, including the Drinking Water State Revolving Fund, for 10 years.

It also establishes a $45 billion program, through the SRF, to replace lead service lines. This is in line with President Biden’s proposed American Jobs Plan.

In addition to investing in our nation’s failing water infrastructure, it would make critical reforms to the Safe Drinking Water Act to improve EPA’s standard setting process and put the agency to work on standards for a few troubling emerging contaminants.

We also know the financial stress on local governments and their water customers have only become more acute due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The AQUA Act authorizes $4 billion for an emergency relief program to provide forgiveness for utility customers facing debts and unpaid fees since March 2020.

This provision was also the subject of our recent legislative hearing as H.R. 3292, introduced by Reps. Dingell and Tlaib, and I thank them for their efforts on this front.

Today we will also consider H.R. 3293, the Low-Income Water Customer Assistance Programs Act, bipartisan legislation introduced by Reps. Blunt Rochester and Katko.

Water affordability is becoming a growing challenge for many American families.

And as our water systems continue to fall into disrepair and have added financial stresses of leaks and main breaks, these issues will only get worse.

Congress provided short-term relief in recent COVID packages, but I believe we must look to establish a permanent program at EPA, similar to how the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program helps families with critical heating and cooling energy costs.

I want to commend Ms. Blunt Rochester for her work on this legislation, which garnered significant support and praise from a diverse group of stakeholders at our legislative hearing last month.

I look forward to working with members to ensure Americans’ most vulnerable families have affordable access to safe water.

Finally, the Subcommittee will consider H.R. 2467, the PFAS Action Act.
Sadly, many Members know how the health and safety of our constituents have been compromised by dangerous PFAS chemicals.

I have visited the communities and met the families who are dealing with PFAS exposure and environmental contamination.

The PFAS Action Act takes a much-needed comprehensive approach to PFAS, including provisions across numerous statutes within our jurisdiction, such as the Safe Drinking Water Act, Superfund, TSCA, and the Clean Air Act.

As a result, this bill would reduce Americans’ exposure to PFAS through our air, water, and consumer products.
It would increase testing, promote consumer awareness, and ensure disclosure, treatment, and remediation when PFAS is released into the environment.

The bill will hold PFAS polluters responsible, require any national drinking water standard to ensure vulnerable groups including pregnant women, infants, and children are protected, and take other critical steps to reduce PFAS exposure and expedite cleanups.

The PFAS Action Act was subject to a robust committee process in the 116th Congress.

It was comprised of over a dozen standalone bills, which were subject to a legislative hearing and a subcommittee markup.

And the reported bill passed the House with bipartisan support in 2020.
We then continued to negotiate with the Senate on many of these provisions.

Despite the change in administration, it is clear Congress needs to continue to push this issue and ensure health-protective steps are taken as quickly as possible.

I want to thank Reps. Dingell and Upton for their continued leadership on PFAS. I hope this is the year we get these provisions across the finish line.

name: James P. McGovern
content:
Votes in Washington prevented me from attending in person, but I was proud to be represented by my staff at this incredible event.

We live in the richest country in the history of the world, yet no community is immune from hunger and food insecurity. Worcester is no exception. Feeding America estimates that 42 million of our fellow citizens may face hunger this year. While those numbers remain elevated as we emerge from a global pandemic that has claimed the lives of 600,000 of our fellow citizens and upended the lives of countless others, the sad reality is that we had a hunger problem long before the pandemic.

As everyone works to return to normal, my charge is that we can do better than that. Congress has made some important improvements to our anti-hunger safety net in the face of this deadly pandemic, but so much more needs to be done. To start, we must not only continue, but we must build upon the investments in SNAP, school meals, summer meals, and tax credits that help working families.

We have reached a critical moment in our work to end hunger once and for all. That’s why I have renewed my call for a White House Conference on Food, Nutrition, Hunger, and Health so we can develop a roadmap to end hunger by 2030. As part of this effort, the House Rules Committee, which I chair, has embarked on a series of hearings, roundtables, site visits, and discussions to examine how hunger impacts our most vulnerable neighbors and how we can make further improvements to anti-hunger programs to ensure no family falls through the cracks.

TELEGRAM.COM
Food distribution event at YMCA feeds 400 families

name: Lisa Murkowski
content: Today I raised Alaska specific priorities with Interior Secretary Deb Haaland during a hearing on the Interior Department’s budget for Fiscal Year 2022. Building on a number of previous conversations with the Secretary, I made very clear that Alaska has proven itself capable of safe, responsible resource development. I emphasized how much of a priority the Willow project is to Alaska and reiterated the sound science and rigorous permitting process that went into allowing that to move forward. I very explicitly asked for Secretary Haaland’s understanding of Public Law Number 115-97, which mandates that two lease sales be held in the 1002 Area of ANWR by 2024 and asked if she believed that she was required by law to carry those lease sales out. For more information, click here: https://bit.ly/3gCTQmW

name: J. Hill
content:
I recently voted in favor of the Harlem Hellfighters Congressional Gold Medal Act, a bill of which I was an original cosponsor. The Harlem Hellfighters were an African American infantry in WWI who spent more time in combat than other American unit and therefore deserve the highest award. This bill would reward this unit with the Congressional Gold Medal -- the highest civilian award bestowed by Congress. This bill is overwhelmingly bipartisan and is an example of the work Congress can do when differences are put aside.

Honoring our servicemembers has always been a top priority for me. I worked with Dr. Brian Mitchell from the University of Arkansas at Little Rock to present the family of Harlem Hellfighter, Leroy Johnston, medals he had earned but never received for his service in World War I. In 2019, my bill, the World War I Valor Medals Review Act was signed into law and requires the Department of Defense to review if more minority service members from WWI are eligible to receive the Medal of Honor.
text: recently voted favor harlem hellfighters congressional gold medal act bill original cosponsor harlem hellfighters african american infantry wwi spent time combat american unit therefore deserve highest award bill would reward unit congressional gold medal highest civilian award bestowed congress bill overwhelmingly bipartisan example work congress differences put asidehonoring servicemembers always top priority worked dr brian mitchell university arkansas little rock present family harlem hellfighter leroy johnston medals earned never received service world war bill world war valor medals review act signed law requires department defense review minority service members wwi eligible receive medal honor

name: Alan S. Lowenthal
content:
I was proud to join the House Natural Resources Committee hearing on Environmental Justice for Coal Country yesterday. We need to understand that rural and tribal coal communities are on the front lines of energy transition and current rules and regulations at the Interior Dept are not providing proper oversight to manage the transition away from a coal economy in many of these communities.

In many cases, these communities are doubly impacted, not just by the environmental impacts of the mining, but also by mining companies’ failure to pay for remediation as the mines close. If we do not strengthen our safeguards, bankrupt coal companies will continue to shed healthcare, pension, and environmental cleanup responsibilities, causing further damage to the communities affected by the coal industry’s decline.

https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/energy_and_environment/house-hearing-highlights-concerns-with-federal-mine-reclamation-oversight-as-state-leaders-look-to-feds/article_13268884-df3b-543e-9846-694d7f6cbc63.html

WVGAZETTEMAIL.COM
House hearing highlights concerns with federal mine reclamation oversight as state leaders look to feds for reclamation help

name: Lisa Murkowski
content:
As a resource development state, Alaska has immense potential at a local, national and global scale. But, despite growing interest to bring domestic resources to market, America continues to rely on foreign countries to meet our oil, gas, and mineral needs. I’ve been doubling down on my efforts to drive policy initiatives to create greater opportunities for America’s domestic energy and critical mineral markets, including through my legislation the Strategic Energy and Minerals Initiative (SEMI) Act and a bill to improve the quality and timeliness of the Federal permitting process. During a recent Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee hearing I emphasized to Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm the importance of capitalizing on America’s domestic energy and critical mineral supply chain. We need to be able to develop the resources we have domestically.

MURKOWSKI.SENATE.GOV
Murkowski Raises Domestic Critical Mineral Supply Chain to Secretary of Energy | U.S. Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska

name: Mike Garcia
content:
The U.S. currently leads the world in space exploration, but it’s also a domain where we can be vulnerable and susceptible to the malicious intent of foes such as China, Russia, & Iran. It is imperative that we continue to invest in our nation's presence and advancement in space.

Any decisions on our part to divest from this adventure will not dissuade our foes from advancing their own space programs.

It would only serve to highlight a massive strategic vulnerability and create capability gaps that will be impossible to close in the future.

As a nation, we are thirsty for something to rally behind that unifies us, something we can all be invested in, intrigued by, and passionate and positive about.

There isn’t a better movement to get behind than our nation’s modern space program.

Watch my full remarks calling for the continued investment in U.S. Space exploration here:

name: Kathy Castor
content:
In an affront to female veterans, House Republicans blocked commonsense legislation that would treat female veterans the same as women in uniform and civilians when it comes to access to health care. GOP members in Congress have become more out-of-touch with mainstream America and also voted to block the Congressional Gold Medal for the Capitol Police and the bipartisan Commission to Investigate the January 6 insurrection. In fact, most Republican members supported the female veterans legislation last year, but have taken a radical turn this Congress.

Women veterans have served our country with honor and deserve equal access to health care once they return home. Our veteran neighbors in Tampa can rest assured that I’ll continue to work to pass this legislation and meet their needs in the days ahead. We owe them the best for their service and sacrifice for our nation.

https://castor.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=403640

name: Rick Larsen
content:
UPDATE ➡️ The House just passed a bill I supported to make Juneteenth a federal holiday.

Why is Juneteenth important? Designating June 19 a national holiday clearly and powerfully proclaims the United States is finally ready to grapple with the legacy of slavery. I invite you to watch a recent panel discussion I had on the history and significance of the holiday with Rep. John Lovick, NAACP Snohomish County’s Louis Harris and Dr. John Fenn from the Library of Congress 📺⬇️

YOUTUBE.COM
Juneteenth Panel Discussion with Rep. John Lovick, NAACP SnoCo's Louis Harris and LOC's John Fenn

Representative Rick Larsen
June 5 at 2:43 PM ·

Had a powerful conversation on the history and importance of Juneteenth with Rep. John Lovick, NAACP Snohomish County's Louis Harris and John Fenn, Head of Research and Programs at the American Folklife Center, Library of Congress.

name: Mario Diaz-Balart
content: Yesterday, the Latino-Jewish Caucus hosted the Argentine House of Representatives President, Sergio Massa. We discussed various important issues, including the delay in resolving the 1994 bombing of the Argentine Israelite Mutual Association (AMIA). We must finally have a transparent investigation of this hateful act and demand that those responsible be brought to justice. I also expressed my great concern over Argentina’s anti-Israel vote at the UN Human Rights Council to create a Commission to investigate the “alleged violations of human rights in Israel and the Gaza Strip,” when Israel has every right to defend itself. Lastly, we spoke about the alarming escalation of anti-Semitism in the region and ways we can work together to end it. Overall, we had a productive conversation, and I am glad to have joined my colleagues to relaunch the Latino Jewish Congressional Caucus for the 117th Congress.
text: yesterday latinojewish caucus hosted argentine house representatives president sergio massa discussed various important issues including delay resolving bombing argentine israelite mutual association amia must finally transparent investigation hateful act demand responsible brought justice also expressed great concern argentinas antiisrael vote un human rights council create commission investigate alleged violations human rights israel gaza strip israel every right defend lastly spoke alarming escalation antisemitism region ways work together end overall productive conversation glad joined colleagues relaunch latino jewish congressional caucus 117th congress

name: Al Lawson, Jr.
content:
Juneteenth (June 19, 1865) is the oldest known celebration commemorating the end of slavery in the United States. This was two and a half years after President Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation.

Today's passing of the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act is an important milestone in our nation's history. It gives us time to reflect on the progress we have made, but also acknowledge the work that still needs to be done. It was an honor to vote in favor of this legislation — for those who came before me who lived, fought and died in pursuit of equality, freedom and liberty.

God Bless America!
https://www.cnn.com/2021/06/16/politics/house-vote-juneteenth-federal-holiday-senate-passed-june-19/index.html

CNN.COM
Congress passes bill making Juneteenth a federal holiday

name: Mike Quigley
content:
This week, I co-sponsored legislation to establish Juneteenth as a federal holiday.

Juneteenth marks the end of one of the original sins of our democracy and should be celebrated as an important piece of Black and American history.

In recognition of the need to make our federal calendar more inclusive and in light of recent action taken by the state of Illinois to make Juneteenth a paid state holiday, my office and I will be observing Juneteenth this year and each year from now on.

name: Aumua Amata Coleman Radewagen
content:
Thank you first of all to the judges for their considered opinion that respected the people of American Samoa and the Samoan Way. Thank you to Mike Williams and the other attorneys at Kirkland & Ellis for their tireless work on behalf of American Samoa and the preservation of our family land and matai heritage. This is truly a blessing, and should set this issue to rest. American Samoa has the right of self-determination. We will continue to insist on our self-determination with great love for the United States. Congress should now act to pass my bill, H.R. 1941, so that U.S. Nationals who choose citizenship can quickly, sensibly and affordably make that change. Individuals should not have roadblocks to their self-determination if they choose citizenship. We thank God for this outcome and will continue to work for these next steps.

Following the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision not to hear an appeal rejecting an almost identical lawsuit in 2016 and a decision by the Biden Administration just last week to continue to use the so-called Insular Cases as a basis for defending federal policy towards the territories, I am calling on the plaintiffs and the special interests behind them in this case to end their assault on the right of the American Samoa people to determine for themselves whether or not to become U.S. citizens... (You can read entire statement here)

https://radewagen.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/amata-s-statement-appellate-decision

RADEWAGEN.HOUSE.GOV
Amata’s Statement on Appellate Decision
text: thank first judges considered opinion respected people american samoa samoan way thank mike williams attorneys kirkland ellis tireless work behalf american samoa preservation family land matai heritage truly blessing set issue rest american samoa right selfdetermination continue insist selfdetermination great love united states congress act pass bill hr us nationals choose citizenship quickly sensibly affordably make change individuals roadblocks selfdetermination choose citizenship thank god outcome continue work next stepsfollowing us supreme courts decision hear appeal rejecting almost identical lawsuit decision biden administration last week continue use socalled insular cases basis defending federal policy towards territories calling plaintiffs special interests behind case end assault right american samoa people determine whether become us citizens read entire statement hereradewagenhousegovamatas statement appellate decision

name: Bruce Westerman
content:
Those with a life-threatening illness or condition know that time is of the essence. I recently reintroduced a bipartisan bill to cut red tape so patients with terminal conditions may quickly access lifesaving treatments with positive clinical data.

The Promising Pathway Act will allow innovative therapies with encouraging clinical trial data to treat patients outside the Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA) rigid trial requirements, promoting innovation, and sparking competition between smaller and larger pharmaceutical companies.

It is common for small companies to complete meaningful Phase II clinical trials, only to run out of funds before they are able to test the drugs in larger populations and eventually bring it to market. Without new investments, larger companies buy the therapy, complete the clinical trials, and market the drug themselves.

Through the Promising Pathway Act, the small company that has proven the safety and efficacy of the therapy will be able to market the drug to individuals outside of the clinical trials, and receive needed investment to finish the late-stage clinical trials. This increases competition between the small and large companies, helps lower drug prices, and brings new therapies to market faster.

This bill is especially important for those suffering from terminal diseases, such as ALS. A patient diagnosed with ALS is typically given no more than 3 years to live. That is not enough time to wait for the FDA to fully approve a therapy that could potentially save his or her life. Through this bill, effective therapies for ALS will more quickly become available to those who desperately need them.

Unlike the established Accelerated Approval process or President Trump’s Right to Try process, the Promising Pathway Act is the only policy that expands treatment options, brings effective therapies to patients quicker, and spurs pharmaceutical competition. Furthermore, the bill ensures that insurance companies must cover the therapy’s costs in the same way they would any fully FDA-approved treatment, relieving patients of the cost burden.

Americans with potentially terminal illnesses deserve every opportunity to change the course of their diagnosis. I am honored to play a small part in that by reintroducing the Promising Pathway Act.

name: Robert E. Latta
content:
Secretary Granholm announced yesterday that the Department of Energy will be taking steps to establish a uranium reserve. The United States should not rely on a foreign uranium supply that can be cut off at any time. I have led legislation that would authorize this exact policy. Plus, I recently sent a #bipartisan letter with eleven of my colleagues urging the Secretary to support nuclear energy and fully fund the establishment of this reserve.

It is essential that the Administration follows through with the uranium reserve to maintain our domestic energy security and provide clean emission-free energy to our nation. I urge Secretary Granholm and the Biden Administration to work with Congress to finally authorize the creation of the domestic uranium reserve.

THEHILL.COM
Biden administration eyes step toward Trump-era proposal for uranium reserve

There's an urgent need to invest in the IRS to bolster tax enforcement. We must fight back against tax cheats to ensure everyone pays their fair share and our government is well-resourced.

name: House Committee on Ways and Means
content:

name: Sanford D. Bishop, Jr.
content:
I’m pleased that Congress is establishing this federal holiday to reflect on America’s history of slavery and the fight to overcome the legacy of this insidious institution as well as the bigotry on which it was built. Though the Emancipation Proclamation ended slavery nearly two and a half years earlier and the 13th Amendment had passed several months prior, news of this development did not reach many former Confederate territories until much later and only made it to Galveston, Texas on June 19, 1865. Since then, many communities across the country have celebrated ‘Juneteenth’ to mark the end of slavery in the United States. This federal holiday allows our country to come together to remember our painful history, rejoice in the progress we’ve made to overcome it, and reaffirm that the fight for equality requires our continued vigilance.

name: Gregorio Kilili Camacho Sablan
content:
We have been largely spared from deaths from COVID-19. But one applicant in the Northern Mariana Islands has received $4,344 to help with Covid-related funeral costs, the Federal Emergency Management Agency reported this week. Congress made this assistance available in the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2021. To be eligible an applicant must be a U.S. citizen, non-citizen national, or qualified alien, who incurred funeral expenses after January 20, 2020. There is no requirement that the deceased person be a U.S. citizen. The death certificate must attribute death to COVID-19. To apply for the aid, call toll-free to 844-684-6333 from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. ET, Monday through Friday.

For more information:
https://www.fema.gov/disasters/coronavirus/economic/funeral-assistance
text: largely spared deaths covid19 one applicant northern mariana islands received help covidrelated funeral costs federal emergency management agency reported week congress made assistance available coronavirus response relief supplemental appropriations act eligible applicant must us citizen noncitizen national qualified alien incurred funeral expenses january requirement deceased person us citizen death certificate must attribute death covid19 apply aid call tollfree pm et monday fridayfor information
