name: Stephen F. Lynch
content:
As Chair of the House Committee on Financial Services FinTech Task Force, I held a hearing yesterday to examine how the use of a Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) might expand access to banking services to unbanked and underbanked communities . As the use of cryptocurrencies and CBDCs continues to develop, it’s important we consider the impact on financial inclusion, consumer privacy, illicit finance protections and business operations. I’d like to thank Dr. Neha Narula from MIT, Carmelle Cadet and all the witnesses who participated in the hearing.

YOUTUBE.COM
Virtual Hearing - Digitizing the Dollar: Investigating the Technological... (EventID=112783)

name: Al Lawson, Jr.
content:
I am a proud product of Florida A&M University, an 1890 Land-Grant institution. It is vital that we provide support to these colleges so they remain competitive in their recruitment efforts, which in turn, will offer a stronger and more diverse cohort of individuals in the nation’s agricultural industry.

During today's Agriculture Committee hearing, "1890 Land Grant Institutions: Investing for Agricultural Resiliency, Equity, and Global Impact," I will speak with leaders from the 1890 land-grant university system to discuss the current state of the 1890s, implementation of the 2018 Farm Bill provisions, their agricultural research and extension needs, and opportunities for further investments to support their mission and impact.

Speakers include:
• Dr. Makola Abdullah: 14th President, Virginia State University
• Dr. Paul Jones: 10th President, Fort Valley State University
• Dr. Heidi M. Anderson: 16th President, University of Maryland Eastern Shore
• Dr. Tony Allen: 12th President, Delaware State University
• Dr. Orlando F. McMeans: Chancellor-Dean, Southern University

Join us live at 10 a.m. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pz9a_dtlWy8

YOUTUBE.COM
1890 Land Grant Institutions: Investing for Agricultural Resiliency, Equity, and Global Impact
text: proud product florida university landgrant institution vital provide support colleges remain competitive recruitment efforts turn offer stronger diverse cohort individuals nations agricultural industryduring todays agriculture committee hearing land grant institutions investing agricultural resiliency equity global impact speak leaders landgrant university system discuss current state 1890s implementation farm bill provisions agricultural research extension needs opportunities investments support mission impactspeakers include dr makola abdullah 14th president virginia state university dr paul jones 10th president fort valley state university dr heidi anderson 16th president university maryland eastern shore dr tony allen 12th president delaware state university dr orlando f mcmeans chancellordean southern universityjoin us live youtubecom1890 land grant institutions investing agricultural resiliency equity global impact

name: Ann Kuster
content:
New Hampshire is leading the nation in utilizing alternative energy sources for heating to cut down on fossil fuels and reduce carbon emissions.

Thank you to the Granite State’s own Rob Riley for advocating on behalf of local and renewable energy solutions!

The Aspen Institute
11 hrs ·

“A recent New York Times article detailed the climate-related pros and cons of using wood pellets for heating in the Southeast United States, along with the rural development and environmental justice costs and benefits of that region’s wood-pellet industry. Aspen CSG knows from its 35 years of work across the nation that rural America is not a monolith – and that economies, assets, cultures, populations, and solutions vary widely across the nation. These regional differences matter. To understand the reality of a different region, we offer the perspective of Rob Riley, CEO of the Northern Forest Center."

Check out this article from the Aspen Institute Community Strategies Group, Rural Development Innovation Group & Northern Forest Center in today’s 5 Best Ideas of the Day: https://www.aspeninstitute.org/ideas/
text: new hampshire leading nation utilizing alternative energy sources heating cut fossil fuels reduce carbon emissionsthank granite states rob riley advocating behalf local renewable energy solutionsthe aspen institute11 hrs recent new york times article detailed climaterelated pros cons using wood pellets heating southeast united states along rural development environmental justice costs benefits regions woodpellet industry aspen csg knows years work across nation rural america monolith economies assets cultures populations solutions vary widely across nation regional differences matter understand reality different region offer perspective rob riley ceo northern forest centercheck article aspen institute community strategies group rural development innovation group northern forest center todays best ideas day

name: Adam Smith
content:
As we continue to work to create a more equitable and sustainable economic future that works for all Americans, we must address growing income inequality and the existential threat of climate change.

By requiring corporations to disclose environmental, social, and good governance metrics, the Corporate Governance Improvement and Investor Protection Act will help empower and inform shareholders, workers, and consumers in their investment and savings decisions.

I strongly support the efforts to account for climate risk in financial services, help shift economic power towards workers, and promote a more sustainable economic future that benefits all Americans.

Read my full statement here: https://adamsmith.house.gov/press-releases?id=37984774-D97C-4179-9752-2A345D101746

ADAMSMITH.HOUSE.GOV
Rep. Smith Votes to Pass Bill Improving Corporate Transparency and Investor Protections

name: Jimmy Gomez
content:
We’re always reading headlines about forgotten places across the U.S. devastated by industry and job loss.

But it’s ridiculous to say these places — like Boyle Heights and East L.A. — were “forgotten”; Black and Brown communities were hand-picked by corporations to be used as dumping grounds and pollution sites.

As we prepare historic investments in our infrastructure, green jobs have to come with a focus on helping right the wrongs of environmental racism that’s plagued these neighborhoods for generations.

ANY bold climate action starts with uplifting the most vulnerable, disadvantaged Americans or it’s not bold enough.
text: always reading headlines forgotten places across us devastated industry job lossbut ridiculous say places like boyle heights east la forgotten black brown communities handpicked corporations used dumping grounds pollution sitesas prepare historic investments infrastructure green jobs come focus helping right wrongs environmental racism thats plagued neighborhoods generationsany bold climate action starts uplifting vulnerable disadvantaged americans bold enough

name: J. Hill
content:
June 9 was the virtual kickoff for The Venture Center and 2021 FIS Fintech Accelerator.

This year, the 12-week program will be held virtually for ten emerging financial technology cohorts from around the world. I am proud that central Arkansas continues to grow into an advancing technology haven, and that we can serve as a model for communities who are hoping to encourage development of their own industries.

Because of this program, multinational companies are coming to central Arkansas to collaborate, learn how to make their businesses more successful, and often times choose to relocate to Little Rock and add to our dynamic and rapidly advancing community. I want to welcome these participants to Arkansas.

https://www.arkansasbusiness.com/article/136051/next-fis-fintech-accelerator-companies-named

name: Derek Kilmer
content:
Puget Sound is our region’s most iconic body of water, a place on which generations have built their lives and made their livelihoods. But if future generations are going to have those opportunities, we've got to take action now to protect and restore the Sound – and we need a strong federal partner in those efforts. That’s why I am proud that yesterday the House passed the PUGET SOS Act – legislation I introduced with Congresswoman Marilyn Strickland to ensure the federal government steps-up to be the partner that state, tribal, and local entities need to save our Sound. This important bill will assist important regional efforts to restore salmon and orca populations, ensure future generations can dig for clams, and uphold tribal treaty rights. I’ll keep working to get this bill signed into law.
https://kilmer.house.gov/news/press-releases/house-passes-kilmer-strickland-bill-to-bolster-puget-sound-restoration-and-recovery-efforts

KILMER.HOUSE.GOV
House Passes Kilmer-Strickland Bill to Bolster Puget Sound Restoration & Recovery Efforts | U.S. Congressman Derek Kilmer of Washington's 6th District
text: puget sound regions iconic body water place generations built lives made livelihoods future generations going opportunities weve got take action protect restore sound need strong federal partner efforts thats proud yesterday house passed puget sos act legislation introduced congresswoman marilyn strickland ensure federal government stepsup partner state tribal local entities need save sound important bill assist important regional efforts restore salmon orca populations ensure future generations dig clams uphold tribal treaty rights ill keep working get bill signed lawkilmerhousegovhouse passes kilmerstrickland bill bolster puget sound restoration recovery efforts us congressman derek kilmer washingtons 6th district

name: Aumua Amata Coleman Radewagen
content:
Congresswoman Amata seeks a wounded warrior or medically retired veteran for a two-year paid fellowship in our American Samoa district office. To qualify, veterans must meet all of the following requirements: Honorably discharged, released from active duty within the last five years, terminal pay grades at or below E-5 or O-3, 20% or greater service connected disabilities (waived if you have a Purple Heart). Veterans who are in receipt of a 20-year or Temporary Early Retirement Authorization (TERA) retirement are not eligible for the program. Interested veterans should go to https://www.usajobs.gov/ and search “Wounded Warrior Fellowship Program” for more information and how to apply.

USAJOBS.GOV
USAJOBS - The Federal Government's official employment site
text: congresswoman amata seeks wounded warrior medically retired veteran twoyear paid fellowship american samoa district office qualify veterans must meet following requirements honorably discharged released active duty within last five years terminal pay grades e5 o3 greater service connected disabilities waived purple heart veterans receipt 20year temporary early retirement authorization tera retirement eligible program interested veterans go search wounded warrior fellowship program information applyusajobsgovusajobs federal governments official employment site

name: Stephen F. Lynch
content:
Proud to support passage of S. 475, the Juneteenth National Independence Day Act, which commemorates the end of slavery in the United States. On June 19, 1865, about two months after the Confederate General Robert E. Lee surrendered at Appomattox Court House, VA, Gordon Granger, a Union general, arrived in Galveston, Texas, to inform enslaved African Americans of their freedom and that the Civil War had ended. General Granger’s announcement put into effect the Emancipation Proclamation, which had been issued more than two and a half years earlier on Jan. 1, 1863, by President Abraham Lincoln. It is important we remember our country’s history as we strive to build a more perfect Union and keep faith with the promise to provide equality and justice for all.

CONGRESS.GOV
S.475 - 117th Congress (2021-2022): Juneteenth National Independence Day Act
text: proud support passage juneteenth national independence day act commemorates end slavery united states june two months confederate general robert e lee surrendered appomattox court house va gordon granger union general arrived galveston texas inform enslaved african americans freedom civil war ended general grangers announcement put effect emancipation proclamation issued two half years earlier jan president abraham lincoln important remember countrys history strive build perfect union keep faith promise provide equality justice allcongressgovs475 117th congress juneteenth national independence day act

name: Brett Guthrie
content:
Deadline is June 23rd for federal disaster assistance and June 22nd for Small Business Administration low-interest disaster loans for Kentuckians in the 31 counties that are part of the Major Disaster Declaration due to storm damages from Feb. 27 – March 14. Jessamine and Warren counties from Kentucky’s Second District are eligible for this assistance. I supported the Major Disaster Declaration and damage assessments. Here’s four ways to apply for assistance:

1. DisasterAssistance.gov

2. Downloading FEMA app and registering

3. Calling 800-621-3362 (TTY 800-462-7585). Open every day from 7 a.m. – 11 p.m.

4. Individual Assistance Registration Support Centers are open for in-person help. You do not need an appointment and you do not have to register for assistance in the same county you reside in. More information on the sites can be found here: https://kentucky.gov/Pages/Activity-stream.aspx?n=GovernorBeshear&prId=811

name: House Committee on Foreign Affairs
content:
This year’s NATO Summit represented more than just 30 democratic allies coming together to discuss shared interests, threats, and challenges. Today’s Summit – following the G7 – was an opportunity for President Biden to demonstrate to our transatlantic allies and to the world that the United States is back and ready to lead.

The United States reaffirmed its commitment to collective defense and to the democratic values that serve as the foundation of the alliance; commitments which the former president’s America alone policies undermined.

name: Robin L. Kelly
content:
As the impacts from the COVID-19 pandemic continue to ripple across our nation, an escalating foreclosure crisis among FHA-insured borrowers is impacting hundreds of thousands of borrowers. Homeowners who may be struggling and unable to make mortgage payments due to the COVID-19 pandemic should look into FHA’s special COVID-19 mortgage payment forbearance program.

Call, email or visit the website of your mortgage servicer using the contact information on your monthly mortgage statement to find out if you qualify for COVID-19 forbearance.

name: Filemon Vela
content:
The U.S. Small Business Administration rollout of the Shuttered Venues Operators Grant program has been plagued by technical challenges and persistent delays. Today, I joined more than 200 colleagues in a bipartisan letter demanding the immediate disbursement of funds. Our small businesses are the engine of our economy, and I will continue to fight to ensure they receive the support they need to see it through this pandemic.
